author: appel11

description.text:
Here's a video of the String Launcher in action. It was inspired by a video I saw by Bruce Yeany. His string launcher is beautiful and I knew I lacked the woodworking skills to replicate it, so I just 3D printed what I would need.

Unfortunately I can't share all the details. I don't know were the motors came from. They were in a box of left over stuff from a physics make and take workshop from 10 years ago or so. However, I made this in Tinkercad and you can easily go in and edit my model to fit what ever motors you happen to find.

Print without supports. Mount the motors at wheels. I used a little masking tape around my motors to make them fit snuggly in the holes. Then glue the string guide to the main body as shown in the picture.

I put a layer of EZ Fuse silicone tape around one of my wheels. This helped increase friction and also close the gap between the wheels a tad.

Then wire the motors so that they will spin to pull the string through. I know you could get away with one motor and one wheel that spins freely. I decided to go with two motors to make mounting the second wheel easier/more reliable.

The only other thing to remember is to feed the string through the string guide before you tie it into a big loop.

• How is it possible to push a string?
  • Can you use the arc to determine the velocity of the string as it leaves the launcher?
  • Does the string fit a model of projectile motion? If so, when does it stop being a projectile?
  • Is this related to the Chain Fountain?

description.text:
The common Testors set comes with 9 bottles of enamel paint, which are roughly around 24mm in width, and around 50mm in height. This 3D set is with 30mm width (a little extra room for layers), and 20mm deep inside each cylinder to expose the can a bit. Additionally, there's two smaller cylinders for the small, white Testors paint brushes to fit in there (they round up to about 5.5mm in width, and these cylinders are 6mm round at 32mm deep -- fits perfectly for the brushes with room to grab them).

The printing settings are completely optional -- due to being a paint holder, you can probably print this at the lowest quality settings to speed things up.

title: Z Rod Assembly Support Anet A8

description.text:
Dear community!

The correct way to install/assemble the Z Rod and Coupler is shown here:

https://3dprint.wiki/reprap/anet/a8/coupler

Most of you know this but who is has still problems with assembly can use this tools here to make sure everything is correct and not crooked.

Tested on Anet A8. Might work on other clones aswell.

Instruction:

  1. Loosen up all bolts on the coupler.
  2. Lift the coupler off the motor shaft.
  3. Position the motor shaft as seen on picture one.
  4. Slide the coupler back on the motor shaft, put the two brackets under the coupler and position the coupler as on picture two shown.
  5. Attache the semmbly support into Z Rod hole and push with the one finger against it.Then slide the z rod into the hole and with your other fingers push against the assembly support. See picture three.
  6. !!! Important !!! Before tigthening the screws. Move with the allen key the coupler couple times to the left and right position so it goes back and forth. This is important to prevent tightening the coupler crooked. See picture four.
  7. Tigthening little by little the screws over cross as seen on picture five. Take your time during this step.
  8. Remove the assembly support and your Z Rod and Coupler is perfectly installed.

Printer:

Anet A8

title: PSU wire cover for Geeetech I3 (12 volt 30 amp 360 watt)

description.text:
this is designed to suit a Geeetech i3X, using lehaiver's cover as a basis because it needed to sit flush with the power supply to allow room for the screw heads holding the Z axis motor mount in place.

holes in the bottom were removed, the back panel was opened up to allow cables coming in from behind, the left side hole was enlarged to allow cables running under the motor to pass through, mounting holes were added on the right side for the power socket. pillars were added with recesses for M3 hex nuts to secure it in place.

i also added a mounting point so i could move the USB port to a more convenient location with the aid of a 50cm extension cord off ebay.

this should suit any acrylic Geeetech I3, possibly aluminium ones too, if they have the same mounting points for a 360 watt power supply.

this design has no mounting point for a switch of any kind, as i have moved mine to the front of the unit with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1576168

i am aware that this object is non-manifold, but cura slices it up without any issues.

Geeetech i3 pro X

print_settings.Notes:: Extra perimeters and high infill ratio are required to make it airtight and keeping it from exploding because of high pressure used.

description.text:
I made this just to see if I could make one of these devises work without much knowledge of their optimum dimensions. Vortex tubes are devices which produce hot and cold air from pressurized air. Vortex tubes are occasionally used by machinists to spot cool items to as low temperatures as −50°C.

I was able to get temperatures 25°C colder than ambient temperature with air pressure of 6bar.

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

50-100%

Notes:

Extra perimeters and high infill ratio are required to make it airtight and keeping it from exploding because of high pressure used.

Glue the nozzle and intake tube with diameter of 6.5-7mm in place with some epoxy/superglue. Apply some pressurized air to the inlet pipe while closing the hot end holes with some tape. The hot end gap is right size when there is just slight breeze coming from the cold end nozzle. Be careful when using for the first time, as there is a chance that the device could blow into pieces. I tested mine at 6bar pressure, but it should withstand up to 10bar pressures. The optimum pressure might be quite low.

description.text:
Motorisation of a basic 1.25" filterwheel, using cheap 28BYJ48 stepper motor and hall sensor for precise positionment.
Designed to be printed in PLA. There is a gear for reduction to the already reduced stepper, so it is really precise. Using a stepper allows to not use any current when the wheel is at its target position.
The whole thing is driven by an arduino Nano, connected to the filterwheel using a RJ45 cable.
This requires drilling two 3mm holes for fixation, and gluing a big wheel around the filters. Make sure you have the exact same filterwheel... Otherwise, the openscad file is provided so you can adjust it.
There is a ball in the filterwheel to make it hold its position. This ball must be removed.

Appart from the printed parts, the BOM is :

  • 28BYJ48 stepper motor with its controller (~3€)
  • One US5881LUA hall sensor with a magnet - 2€ at MC Hobby
  • An Arduino Nano board
  • RJ45 connectors and cables

The filterwheel I used appears with different names. (at least here )

I also built an ASCOM driver that allow using the filterwheel from most astro software under windows.

Schematics & more details are available here (french only) :

http://pludov.blogspot.fr/2016/08/roue-filtre-motorisee-la-mecanique.html

Source code for the Ascom driver is on github

title: Bosch quick clamping chuck handgrip refurbished

description.text:
This is the v2 of the Bosch quick clamping chuck handgrip.

Because it may not be easy to find an electrical connector with the same dimensions as I used in the previous version, I have redesigned the assembly by replacing the retaining part with a 16 mm M4 cheese head screw and a nut.

The screw only prevents the stem from coming out.

Insert the nut before gluing both parts.

If the FreeCad design is edited, cut the stl file on the Z axis to 16,75 mm with the NetFabb. Rotate bottom 180º before printing.

Mango para portabrocas Bosh de cierre rápido remodelado.

Esta es la v2 del Bosch quick clamping chuck handgrip.

Debido a que puede no ser fácil encontrar una ficha de conexión eléctrica con las mismas medidas que usé en la versión anterior, he rediseñado el montaje cambiando la pieza de retención por un tornillo M4 con cabeza cilíndrica ranurada de 16 mm (incluida la cabeza) y una tuerca.

El tornillo solo impide que se salga el vástago.

La tuerca se debe insertar antes de pegar ambas partes.

Si se edita el diseño de FreeCad, cortar la pieza en el eje Z a 16,75 mm con el NetFabb. Girar la parte inferior 180º antes de imprimir.

a simple remix, moves the speaker hole to the back plate, increases the height slightly and removes some unneeded geometry for a lidless enclosure to suit the acrylic Geeetech i3X, which has the LCD panel mounted at the top of the frame and a reverse mounted speaker.

M3 sized spacers are included to offset the board by the correct amount to give it a snug fit, you may need to rescale these in the Z axis a little to suit your needs, and the x/y may need to be adjusted to 1.1 or so.

installation is a little tricky, i would suggest test fitting everything first to make sure the spacers are the correct length, and strongly recommend using some sort of adhesive or double sided tape to attach the spacers to the circuit board - this will save you a lot of headaches.

title: Wolfcraft 4800 Drill Holder Rotary Tool Adapter

description.text:
It is an adapter for attaching a rotary tool to the Wolfcraft 4800 drill holder. I don't know if it supports the 4802 model, although it could be adapted by modifying the design of the bottom (warning: it is a truncated cone, not a cylinder, at least on the 4800).

I made 3 designs with different band clamp diameter:

  • 44 mm, which allows to hold rotary tools between 42 and 46 mm approximately.
  • 47 mm, between 45 and 49 mm.
  • 50 mm, between 48 and 52 mm.

The bottom window allows attaching the adapter to a table using a little F or G type clamp.

Before joining the two parts, insert a M6 x 40 mm screw with a hex head. Use PVC pipe cement preferably or acetone (if you print in ABS).

Once dry, put a washer and a wing nut.

Adaptador de miniherramienta para soporte de taladro Wolfcraft 4800

Se trata de un adaptador para acoplar una miniherramienta de tipo Dremel al soporte para taladro Wolfcraft 4800. No se si es compatible con el soporte 4802, aunque se podría adaptar modificando el diseño de la parte inferior (ojo: es un cono truncado, no un cilindro, al menos en el 4800).

He realizado 3 diseños con distintos diámetros de la abrazadera:

  • 44 mm, que permite sujetar miniherramientas entre 42 y 46 mm aproximadamente.
  • 47 mm, entre 45 y 49 mm.
  • 50 mm, entre 48 y 52 mm.

La ventana de la parte inferior permite sujetar el adaptador a una mesa usando un gato o un sargento pequeño.

Antes de unir las dos partes, insertar un tornillo M6 x 40 mm con cabeza hexagonal. Usar preferentemente pegamento para tuberías de PVC o acetona para pegarlas (si se imprime con ABS).

Una vez seco, poner una arandela y una tuerca de palometa.

title: Bedini SG style motor (mechanical components)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here is a easy and fast to print model of an Bedini SG motor.

You have to get some additional parts for a successful assembly of this kit.

  • 2 x Ball bearing 15 x 10 x 4 mm (typical outer wheel bearing of front axle of an Axial RC model). You should get these bearings at your local RC Store.
  • 22 x Screw 3 x 12 mm (special thread for plastic). Also used on Axial RC cars, so you should find these screws also in your local RC store.
  • 24 neodynum magnets 8mm in diameter, 5mm in hight (you only need 8 if you use the 8 magnet rotor).
  • some welding rods for the iron core of the coil
  • 250m of 0.2mm magnet wire and 250m of 0.3mm magnet wire
  • the components to built the elctronic circuit (can be found on Internet)

these parts have to print more than once:

2 x rotor_stand.stl
2 x connector.stl
4 x rubber_feet.stl

Assembly tips:

glue together the upper and lower part of the coil. Complete your coil by adding the iron core and the coil wires. Screw your finished coil to the part mounting_plate.stl.
Place the part center_rod.stl in the midlle hole of part rotor_xx_magnets.stl then screw on the hubs. Also add the magnets (maybe you have to grind the holes with a Dremel to fit the magnets properly)
After that you have to press the ball bearings into the parts rotor-stand.stl. Screw one rotor_stand.stl to the mounting plate (bearing faces towards the rotor). Add the rotor. Screw on the parts connector.st (connects the 2 rotor stands) and the second rotor stand.
The parts rubber_feet.stl will be glued to the lower side of the mounting plate.
Add your bedini circuit and start the motor!!

Have fun with this kit!!!

title: Mountable Cable Tamer for Netgear GS108PEv_3 8-port POE Switch

description.text:
Update 2017-01-09: Noticed that one of the OEM screws on the 20mm high version does punch through into the side of one of the channels. Until I move the channel a bit, shorten the screw a few mm or use shorter screws to be safe.

A 20mm tall and low profile 11.22mm tall mountable base with built-in cable channels so you can route the patch cables under the switch, keeping the switch stable on a shelf/table, and still see the activity LEDS on the ports. Cable channels are designed at 6mm wide and are sized based on the CAT6 patch cables I have on-hand. The organizer is designed to use the manufacturer-supplied mounting screws and the rubber feet are to remain in place on the housing to help hold everything together. I added some 1/4" clear rubber feet to the bottom of the pictured printouts to keep the setup from wandering. For the low-profile mount, the screws will need cut down to 11mm or alternate screws used (linesman pliers are sufficient for cutting down the OEM screws). I prefer the low-profile due to the decrease in material and print time. Otherwise, there is very little functional difference. I've included the original Sketchup skp files so feel free to remix as you like. If you have specific requirements for this setup, reach out and I'll see if I can accommodate.

title: Remix: Mermaid Cookie Cutter with stamp

description.text:
Mermaid Cookie Cutter with stamp

This two-part cutter is derived from the Mermaid Cookie Cutter by No3DoB (see remix source files).

After printing and testing the cutter I've noticed that especially the finer structures are hard to get out of the cutter. At first I just wanted to get rid of the smaller detail,but I liked the mermaid outline so much that I decided to go for a two-part cutter with a cutting and a stamping part.

This is still a work in progress, and I've not yet been able to test it in print. It is possible for the clearance between the cutter and the stamp to be quite tight.

Just print both the cutter and the stamp part and later use the stamp to imprint the mermaid outline and push the dough out of the cutter part.

title: Bec refroidissement pour tête d'impression DiscoEasy200 / Cooling hose for HotEnd on DiscoEasy 200

description.text:
Edit : 22-01-2017

Le bec asymétrique Version 2 a un flux optimisé pour ne pas trop refroidir la buse. Les contours ont été adoucis pour ne pas accrocher les supports ou les défauts d'extrusion.

The asymetrical hose has a better flow orientation to not cool the hotend too much, just filament. Edges have been smoothed to avoid support or extrusion artefacts hooking.

Texte précedent:

Je voulais tester le l'optimisation du refroidissement avant de faire une nouvelle tête complète.
Ces 2 versions permettent de tester les effets d'un cooling optimisé sans refaire une tête complète ni abîmer (un peu de ponçage/collage mais la tête restera fonctionnelle si on fait marche arrière) la tête actuelle.
Pour monter ces becs (l'un ou l'autre selon la position réelle du corps de chauffe), il suffit de poncer un peu l'excroissance à côté du palpeur et de coller avec un peu de cyano, les pattes du bec. On peut également étanchéifier le raccord avec un peu de cyano.

I wanted to test cooling optimisation before design a whole new printing head.
Theses version allow both to test effets of an optimised cooling without destroy your guenuine print head. Just a bit of sanding and glue but you can go back easily.

title: Tiny Whoop Camera Mount (One Size Fits All) - FX798t, F-01, TX-01, Etc...

description.text:
A fine gent created a nice alternative for mounting the camera when doing a mullet mod. this style mounts on the camera lens barrel instead of the base. This seems to end up with a lighter mount that's more versatile. I've used it on a bunch of different cameras with success (only one of which was actually a mullet mod).

The camera is really in there, too!

The original design was just at a reasonable extreme angle for my tastes so I remixed it to be less aggressive. I think this is like 5 degrees or something. Either way the camera will sag a little bit in the mount and, for me, it's perfect.

Two designs here: one is pretty much just a lower angle version. The other is the same thing with the top cut off - if you use this you'll need some 3M VHB tape (just a tiny amount) or similar. I used that for both options ... maybe both need it ... The reasoning behind the second design is two fold: With the tape, it's actually kind hard to remove the camera. If you do want to put a canopy on, the tall tabs get in the way, you can just trim them post print :)

comments.text: I like it. Also, if anyone wants to adjust the angle, it can be done with a steady hand and a soldering iron with ease.

comments.text: Nice! The reason I put the taller tabs was that it helped in inverted crashing.

title: 40mm fan blades
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Small filesize. Maximizes blade width. Unlike some other replacement fans, this design replaces the entire blade ring and maximizes efficiency. Other designs have you print blades on a ring that you need to slide over the old one, which results in +/-20% less blade surface width.

I have printed and tested it (early versions were still WIP), and the design now works. Follow these steps:

0/ Read all the steps before doing anything
1/ Download and print the files. Print with 0.8mm walls, supports should not be necessary, depending on your printer and settings. It printed fine on my $150 3D printer with cheapo Hobbyking filament, without supports.
2/ Disassemble your fan, separate the blades from the rest of the motor
3/ Trim your blades entirely, including the ring, so that you're just left with the flat circle and the magnet sticking out in the middle. Don't throw away the magnetic ring that fits inside.
4/ Put the "center spacer" (the cross with the circle in the middle) into the blades you just printed.
5/ Use the hole of the center spacer to fit the magnet, so when you glue or melt the backside with the magnet to the fanblades, that you have them centered. (see picture) Try fitting everything together before glueing or melting parts together. If you notice the backside sticking out of the motor, you may want to print the model again, but at a slightly decreased Z height (like 5.4 or even 5 instead of 6 mm... keep your layer height in mind) or gently sand the bottom down a bit, or simply use a spacer.
6/ Attach (glue/melt/..) the blades to the backside with the magnet.
7/ Pull out the center spacer and throw it away.
8/ Insert the magnetic ring
9/ Push the blades back into the rest of the motor. Make sure none of the blades touch the walls, if so, push/pull the fanblades out, trim where needed. This wasn't the case for me, but just to be sure, check it.
10/ Mount the motor.
11/ Success!

https://youtu.be/1YmQFGr22ys

//////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
old info down below:
//////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
EDIT 1: Oops! version updated already, i noticed a part of a boolean was included, which should not have been included, making the ring too thick- it was also mirrored (sad face)

EDIT 2: So i did get around to printing the model, and it was just not tight enough. Probably didn't measure it accurately enough (don't own a fancy schmancy digital caliper yet), so i uploaded a new version, which should be a tighter fit, with the added benefit of the blades being a tad longer too, due to the extra space coming from the smaller ring. I haven't printed this one yet, but it should be better.

experimental and untested! The ring in the middle should be 0.8mm thick, which should make it easier for a 0.4mm nozzle. The idea is to trim the original down to the round flat surface, You'll need to glue (or melt) both together.

I haven't printed or tested it, since i already got my replacement and didn't feel the need to, but i already made the 3D model, so i decided to share it nevertheless. Please leave feedback if you printed it.

LOW POLY & SMALL FILE SIZE (55k)

Extra Parts

  • Tap drill bits: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/New-5PCS-Set-HSS-M3-M4-M5-M6-M8-Machine-Spiral-Point-Straight-Fluted-Screw-Thread/32558965348.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.asvjj6

  • 9 pieces of 5mm x 1mm neodymium magnets: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/100-pcs-Disc-Rare-Earth-Neodymium-Super-Strong-Magnets-N35-Craft-Mode-HH1/32610921145.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.N5YP8T

  • One 20mm M3 allen screw (see the picture below for the exact model)
Insert every tap drill bit into their specific adapter. If you add some CA glue to the adapter hole, the drill will hold to it better Insert a 20mm M3 screw into the handle hole, to make it strong against torsion forces. Glue some EVA rubber on the brackets, to allow the adapters/drills fit tightly. Get a CD cover trasparent plastic piece and put 1 magnet under it (that's why 9 magnets instead 8). Put 4 magnets, one at a time over the previous CD cover / magnet and mark them in red color. Now, flip the maget under the CD cover and repeat the previous process, with other 4 magnets, only, this time, marking them in blue color. Now, glue the red magnets to holes on the bottom part of the box, using some CA glue Also glue the blue magnets to the top part (box cover).

Now it's done, make the best use of your tools

title: Geeetech i3X belt holder with touch probe mount

description.text:
i wanted to replace the belt fixtures on my x and y axes with the slot-in type attachment as opposed to punching holes and using screws to reduce the chances of a belt tearing as a result. with the X axis one i also wanted a simple way to neatly route the fan and motor wires behind the carriage to a nice low point below my smooth rods. i figured while i was at it, i'd include a mounting point for a touch probe that positioned it behind the hot end.

i used glue to attach the probe mount so that the probe had no offset at all in the X axis, and i ended up with a 60mm offset in the Y axis.

when fixing the probe mount in place, i first levelled my bed and moved my z axis to the home position. i slid a piece of paper between my build plate and nozzle, then sat the probe, attached to the mount with washers installed as spacers, on top of my 8.3mm gauge block. i smeared some silicone adhesive on the bracket and pushed it into position, then held everything steady until the glue cured sufficiently. in my case, everything lined up perfectly.

as an added bonus, the touch probe now acts as a carriage mounted light source, illuminating the build from above and behind, giving just enough light at just the right angle to be able to see everything that's going on. in fact, i'm considering ordering some white SMD LEDs and replacing the red one in the probe.

Printer:

Geeetech i3 pro X

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

35%

Notes:

note that there is a built-in support piece at the mounting point for the touch sensor bracket which will need to be removed.

you will need: 4 M3 washers, 4 square M3 hex nuts and some M3 screws (not sure of exact length needed, i think they were like 12mm or so) to attach the belt mounts, all the screws and nuts that came with your touch probe, and some strong adhesive - but not polyacrylite/super glue. ideally you want a glue that gives you a small amount of working time to allow you to position and adjust the probe mount precisely. i recommend a gauge block to aid you in this. i used silicone adhesive so that if i REALLY need to i can still remove the mount.

So I designed a mini-spinner that works great for small hands. The photo shows this mini spinner next to a full-size version I found elsewhere on thingiverse (I didn't design the bigger one).

This one uses 4x11x4 bearings. I had a few leftover after changing out the extruder contraption on my printer, so I made this to put them to good use. Print two of the bearing caps to press into the middle of the center bearing to give it something to hold on to while it spins.

The holes are designed to exactly fit the 11mm bearings. If your printer struggles a bit and you find the fit is too tight or too loose, you might want to print it just slightly bigger or smaller in your slicer to make it fit.

Proper belt tension is quite important and therefore here is the method I used for my Geeetech Al Prusa I3. The method is quite simple mainly because the Geetech quite surprisingly uses a properly designed idler pulley and adjustment system for X and Y (I replaced the not recommended smooth pulleys by toothed ones).

Here the pulley is held in a U shaped part with one screw in line with the belt used to hold and adjust it.

The method applies to similar designs. Note that it is quite surprising the wild contraptions some "designers" come up with for such simple things as an idler pulley with often separate adjustment mechanism leading to skewed pulleys, belt, hard to adjust tension ...

As can be seen, I replaced the nut by a butterfly nut, then made a hook for the scale using a piece of M3 threaded spacer plus a piece of threaded rod.

To adjust is simple, just attach a small electronic scale, pull on it till you read the required force then adjust the nut in such a way it just touch the frame, "That's all folks ! "

A proper tension is about 13N for a GT2 6mm wide therefore you have to adjust for around 26N (about 2.6kgf).

Note that if you machine is one of these crappy ones made out of acrylic sheets watch out that it may bend and even break so you now have an excuse to get rid of it :)

author: agccga

title: Adafruit NeoPixel Ring 12 Leds Fitting Cover

description.text:
I integrated a 12 pixel neopixel ring into my printer to act as a temp gauge when warming up and cooling down, then just a random color fading widget while at temp. I used FKOne's mount as a backing to attach it to my printer. It needed a little bit of a diffuser and I had some glow-in-the-dark filament handy so I made this snap fit cover for it.

The result is three 0.3mm layers of solid fill glow-in-the-dark filament and a ring that snaps over the frame. I might add a few more layers later or make it so it stands off of the frame a little further but I'm satisfied with it for now.

Let me know if you're interested in my wiring and code.

UPDATE 8/6/2017
Here are the changes I made to my Marlin code:
Add the Adafruit Neopixel library .h and .ccp files to the same folder Marlin is in.
Find the function "void manage_inactivity" and add the following to the last line of the function:

 "dispTempGauge(); //Call's Dan's temp gauge"

Add the following function: (I added it below the Temp_Stat_LEDs fuction)

//
// Begin Dan's Custom Coloring!!
// 
//
unsigned long previousMills = 0;
unsigned long currentMills = 0;
int guage_type = 2; //default to display off
int guage = 3;

void dispTempGuage(){
  int8_t cur_extruder = 0;

  currentMills = millis();
  if (currentMills - previousMills > 200) { // Update every 0.2s
    previousMills = currentMills; 
    if ((isHeatingHotend(cur_extruder)) && (degTargetHotend(cur_extruder)>100.0) && ((degTargetHotend(cur_extruder)-degHotend(cur_extruder))>2)){
      guage_type = 1; //if heating up && target is set high && not there yet 
    }
    else if(degHotend(cur_extruder)>150.0){ //if not heating and temp is above minimum then dance
      guage_type = 2;
    }
    else if(degHotend(cur_extruder)>30.0){ //when done dancing then show cool down from prev temp setting?
      guage_type = 3;//busy printing
    }
    else{ //if none of the above then the printer must be idle. turn all lights off.
      guage_type = 0; //lights off
    }

    switch (guage_type){
    case 0://off
      for(int i=0;i<NUMPIXELS;i++){
        pixels.setPixelColor(i,0,0,0);
      } 
    break;
    case 1: //Heating
      pixels.setPixelColor(0,128,0,0); //Pixel 0 is Hot sample
      pixels.setPixelColor(1,0,128,0); //Pixel 1 is Green status
      pixels.setPixelColor(2,0,0,128); //Pixel 2 is Cold sample
      guagecolor = pixels.Color(map(degHotend(active_extruder),20,degTargetHotend(cur_extruder)-2,0,128),0,map(degHotend(active_extruder),20,degTargetHotend(cur_extruder)-2,128,0));
      guage = map(degHotend(active_extruder), 20, degTargetHotend(cur_extruder)*.99, 3, 11); //maxTemp*.90 is to scale the max pixel down slightly. Otherwise max is firm MAX.
      for(int i=3;i<guage+1;i++){
        pixels.setPixelColor(i,guagecolor);
      }
      for(int i= guage+1;i<NUMPIXELS;i++){
        pixels.setPixelColor(i,0,0,0);
      }
    break;
    case 2: //busy printing so show random fades
      for(int i=0;i<NUMPIXELS;i++){
        colorR[i] = constrain(colorR[i]-fade,0,255);
        colorG[i] = constrain(colorG[i]-fade,0,255);
        colorB[i] = constrain(colorB[i]-fade,0,255);
        pixels.setPixelColor(i,colorR[i],colorG[i],colorB[i]);
      }

      index=random(NUMPIXELS);
      colorR[index]=random(174);
      colorG[index]=random(174);
      colorB[index]=random(174);
      pixels.setPixelColor(index,colorR[index],colorG[index],colorB[index]);
    break;
    case 3: //cooling
      pixels.setPixelColor(0,64,0,0); //Pixel 0 is Hot sample
      pixels.setPixelColor(1,0,64,0); //Pixel 1 is Green status
      pixels.setPixelColor(2,0,0,64); //Pixel 2 is Cold sample
      guagecolor = pixels.Color(map(degHotend(active_extruder),20,210,0,64),0,map(degHotend(active_extruder),20,210,64,0));
      guage = map(degHotend(active_extruder), 20, 210*.98, 3, 11); //maxTemp*.98 is to scale the max pixel down slightly. Otherwise max is firm MAX.
      for(int i=3;i<guage+1;i++){
        pixels.setPixelColor(i,guagecolor);
      }
      for(int i= guage+1;i<NUMPIXELS;i++){
        pixels.setPixelColor(i,0,0,0);
      }
    break;
    }
    pixels.show();
  }
}

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

description.text:
I made this lens cap for my camera and because I'm very happy with this I will share it here. You can use ABS or PLA or others. Yiu have to print 2 parts ( Cap and Spring) and you need 2 M3 x 6mm screws. The spring has two little rips. to print this in a good quality you should set the layer hight to max. 0.15mm.

1) Print the parts
2) Drill the 2 bores in the spring to 2.5mm and cut a M3 threat in there.
3) Screw spring and cap together as shown on the pictures

Have fun

Peter

title: Shelf Mount for Cheap DC/DC Power Supply

description.text:
First saw these on hack-a-day. These cheap ($30ish) DC/DC power supplies are readily available on amazon, ebay, ect. These units come in a variety of specs so make sure you get one that will work for you. They require you to come up with your own enclosure. I opted to hang mine from a shelf overhanging my desk. I wanted this to be modular so I could keep adding them across.

This version is getting DC in from a 12v supply on the shelf above. This solution does not solve for organizing whatever AC/DC converter you end up with.

I printed this face down. If you decided to do this, check the width of your shelf. Also check the diameter of your banana plugs. Would not hurt to insure your device is the same size (these sorts of things are not known for their consistency). I also put a command velcro strip between the front of the shelf and the enclosure to prevent it from moving around if wires are tugged.

title: Snap together case for a i86, i86L and Eagle n6 Multi Controller Board.

description.text: Snap together case for a 40mm x 40mm i86L or i86 board.

This is a 40mm x 40mm fitted case for a i86L, i86 Eagle n6 mutli controller board. With 10% infill and 2 shells, the case weighs 8 grams (PLA). It is quite stiff and should hold up well. The case snaps together but you might want to put a few dabs of hot glue to hold the case together during flight for added protection. You don't want the top to vibrate off. I've cut 4 pieces of double stick tap and placed it under the board to reduce vibration during flight. This case was designed in Autodesk Inventor 2013. I've included all the files for anyone to use and modify and enjoy!! Update: 12/16/2013
Lowered the clip on the bottom3 part. May have to sand to fit. Also fits a Eagle n6 control board.

print_settings.Notes:: Some parts do not need support, the legs and arms that are straight can print uprofht, socket side down and print fine.  There is not enough contact area for the ball ends to adhere to the raft and print without failing on my machine.  However, the amount of support residue for the parts printed flat is minimal.

description.text:
I have been experimenting with ball and socket joints since I first got the MakerBot years ago. Took a while to find a combination that I am happy with. This iteration is a 0.4" diameter socket with a .403" diameter ball. This provides some interference on the joint so that it holds position. Unfortunately, with the creep in the PLA the joints over time to soften up. This joint provides a bit over 180 degrees of rotation in the primary axis, without controlling the rotation along the limbs axis.

This is a posable figure that is intended to be a framework for other parts. I am working on different sets of heads and covers for the torso and limbs that would snap over the frame.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

fine

Infill:

50% with 4 shells

Notes:

Some parts do not need support, the legs and arms that are straight can print uprofht, socket side down and print fine. There is not enough contact area for the ball ends to adhere to the raft and print without failing on my machine. However, the amount of support residue for the parts printed flat is minimal.

title: desk bridge lamp with LED stripes
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a LED desk lamp. My intention was to create a lamp with less support material and which is easy so assemble.
The cover parts have the purpose to produce an indirect lighting. They can be modified with different patterns to create a new look.
It´s possible to glue the parts, but it´s not necessary. I reduced the thickness of the connection because it was a little bit too tight. I think i printed the parts a little bit too fast, but with the thinner connection it fits good. The foot is formed like the root of a tree and i created also a little container to put some sand in it to make the foot heavier, but it´s not necessary for a good stand on your desk.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

35%

Notes:
  • 3 outline perimeters
  • 5 top and bottom layers

It´s not necessary to bolt or stick the foots to the desk, but it´s necessary to stick some piece of rubber pad unter the foots. That increases the stability of the construction immensely, because then the foots can´t slip apart. When the foots are stable at the ground, the strain is consistent over the profile.

remixed_from.title: "Spiked" RC car wheel for winter bashing

description.text:
This is a remix of kallaspriit's "Spiked" RC car wheel.

It is designed to fit a 12mm hex, but the solidworks (2013) source file is available if you wish to make is smaller or larger for your needs.

I printed my rim at 25% infill with PLA and it held up decently well. I ran the car very hard over numerous jumps for 30 minutes straight in 15 degree weather today. I lost a couple of the spikes, but I feel that is because I was running it in very thin snow. I suspect it would work much better in deeper snow or sand. It would also be better if printed in ABS.

Even with loosing some spikes the car launched and turned extremely well. I handled 100x better than it did with the stock tires on it. I only put the tires on the driving wheel. If you have a 4x4 I would recommend printing 4, otherwise 2 should be good enough.

Videos of the Tires in action below.
https://youtu.be/-rATlOS2ghs – Car Launch
https://youtu.be/X5ZjaoPcoeQ - Off Roading
https://youtu.be/X-bP7fs1Uwo - RC Track

V2 has been uploaded. It has much larger inner and outer spikes that shouldn't break, even when printed in PLA and when used in super cold temps.

If you print either wheel type please upload pics and comment on how they work for you. I would love feedback and can make changes if needed or desired.

25% +

Rotate the part -90 degrees about the x axis to print. The inner hex shape should be facing up.

Simple device to grow avocado trees. Fits on regular household cups and glasses.

Steps

  1. Put the avocado holder on the cup (ideal for ikea cups)
  2. Put avocado seed into the grower
  3. Pour water over the seed, into the cup, so that half of the seed is in water and the other half is out of water
  4. After the seed has grown roots and a stem, plant it into a planter with soil.

title: Bowden X-Carriage Mount for E3D V6
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Consider supporting me by sending me a tip on thingiverse or PayPal.

paypal.me/jackwaterfall

Make sure to post a make if you print one!

Updates

31/07/2017 - New sensor mounts, support for SN04-N sensor. Included cable clamp to clamp cables to the top of the mount for better cable management. Improved fan duct placement and design.

17/02/2017 - Added a BlTouch sensor variant.

13/01/2017 - Added an 18mm sensor variant.

08/01/2017 - First release.

What Is It?

If you are upgrading your Prusa i3 hotend to the E3D V6 or a V6 clone hot-end with the standard groove mount, you'll need some way of mounting it to your x-carriage. The mount attaches to the x-carriage using the same four hole mounting system that is used on the Prusa I3 rework 1.5 kit, so you will need to print off a compatible x-carriage.

My Prusa I3 X-Carriage: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2514659

This design uses a clamp so your hotend will stay firmly in place and won't wobble around.

More features are on the way including cable chain support and dual extrusion options. Please comment on anything you want me to implement and let me know of any problems that you are having with my design.

Notes

Thanks to Josef Prusa. I took inspiration from the Prusa MK2s.

Parts Required

4 x m3 25mm screws
4 x m3 16mm screws
3 x m3 20mm screws
10 x m3 nuts

E3D Hot end (or clone)
30mm fan
50mm radial fan
12mm inductive sensor (or optional 18mm sensor)

Post Processing parts

I designed the parts so that they shouldn't need any cleanup. So just print the parts and you are ready to assemble it.

Assembly

1) Firstly use 4 x m3*25mm screws and 4x m3 nuts to secure the main body of the mount onto your x carriage.

2) Use 2 x m3*16mm screws and 2 x m3 nuts to clamp the hot end onto the main mount using the printed clamp part.

3) Use 2 x m3*20mm screws and 2 x m3 nuts to attach the 50mm radial fan onto the printed clamp part.

4) Use 2 x m3*16mm screws to attach the 30mm fan to the left-hand side of the hot end.

5) Use an m3*20mm screw and an m3 nut to attach the fan duct to the printed camp part just below the radial fan.

18mm Sensor

define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 32.5
define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 5
define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0

comments.author: jgilbs

comments.text: You have to set the z offset and auto-level probe positioning in your slicer or in the firmware. There are other setup and configuration considerations, too, but making sure the offset is set properly for X, Y, and Z will get you going. The probe locations have to take the offset into account.  Say your X offset is 30 (that's mine using the SN4 sensor).  You don't take that as a given.  You have to set the left bed position to be larger than that. description.text:
This is Calamari's model, but with some changes done to make the model easily printable without supports. I started with Calamari's model because it has such nice detail in most of the model.

In particular, each of the four minarets has three observation decks. Under them were cylindrical projections that represent decorative elements in the original structures. The way these are placed, they're accurate to the original structure, but impossible to print without supports, so I've eliminated them. At the same time, I added slopes on the undersides of the decks to smooth out the overhang (the original structure has fluted, decorative eves, so this fits anyway).

I added slopes under the eves of the chhatris at tops of the minarets, and gave a similar treatment to the four larger ones surrounding the large dome on the roof of the main tomb.

I've thickened up the walls around the minarets' upper observation decks a little bit (Slic3r kept splitting them into many small pieces). The spires at the tops of the domes don't render well, being so thin, but I can't thicken them without distorting the model.

There are still some non-manifold polys here and there, but not enough to cause Slic3r to mess up the model.

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Use a wide brim at the bottom of the model - the round "corners" under the four minarets may want to lift off of the build plate, even with good filament and clean glass.

The pictured print was done with with Atomic "Perfect Orange", 0.4mm line width, 60 mm/sec, 45 second minimum layer time, and lots of airflow. Print time was about 11½ hours.

I feel the need to point out one thing: to be accurate to the original building, the four domed chhatris on top of the main building/tomb, and the smaller ones that form the tops of the minarets should all have been eight-sided, rather than six, but doing so would have made them too fragile to print.

description.text:
Description:

A widget that holds four 12V white LED strips on a ring
that fits around the base of a Nikon binocular microscope
with a 2.39 inch diameter ring.

This is a "big" build for my Monoprice Select Mini. It takes
a while to print (more than four hours).

It uses a three element LED strip that was cut off a reel that I
bought surplus.

See the top of the scad file to find the various parameters that
can be adjusted to fit whatever LED strip you may have, and to
fit the collar on your microscope.

The LED strips are held in place with hot melt glue, and the
collar is held onto the scope body with the same. (Moto:
"Why use a screw, when you've got hot melt glue?") Yes it is
ugly, but my shop is for tinkering, not for gazing at.

License:

See the LICENSE.txt file for copyright and conditions for re-use.

description.text: I had problems printing the Mendel x-360-z-bearing plates on the makerbot where the short areas around the bolt holes would cause the part to fail if the filament did not stick perfectly.  I modified the design to add more material on the ends of the part to make the part easier to print.

comments.text: I find that adding multiple STL files to the same build (like mulitply in skeinforge) can sometimes improve quality of thin parts.  Moving the nozzle away on each layer allows it to cool.  I think there is even a skeinforge function that does this.
comments.author: rplumley

description.text: I couldn't get a DSLR to stay in place on the printed platform, though it worked great for a compact.  I had a mini tripod that I never use with a nice aluminum ball-joint head that was really easy to remove.   Modified a collar piece to mount it to and it works great.

I happened to have a dusty mini-tripod with a head held on by a single hex-socket screw.  Made the mounting hole on this thing 6mm in diameter to fit. 
I have a headless mini tripod for sale.  CHEAP.

Se trata de una boquilla para tubo de silicona convencional con salida múltiple, la diseñe para pegar una serie de cristales esmaltados en la pared de mi cocina, con la boquilla pretendo aplicar a la superficie completa una capa de silicona de al menos 2mm de grosor, seria mas efectivo utilizar una pistola aplicadora con control de volumen de salida

para adapta al cartucho de silicona basta con usar una cánula estándar (la que biene con cada bote dse silicona) cortada con un diámetro de 7mm en la punta y la cánula tiene que ser pegada a la boquilla de 8 salidas, yo utilice una mezcla de abs y acetona para pegarlo pero pueden hacerlo con cualquier pegamento capaz de pegar ambos materiales

description.text:
This is a design of a speaker for smartphones I made using a Pringles can.

The speaker is made of three sort of parts. Firstly, as I said, a pringles can, which holds the actual speaker and the cone (Part04). Then we have the 3D-printed parts, which you can download right here, and last, but nos least, the electronic components, the core of this project.

The idea of this thing is to have a holder for a smartphone so you have it stood in vertical position linked with the audio jack, while you hear your music with the speaker. The audio jack holder (P02) designed to be adjustable, so it can fit different types of phones or audio players.
See it in action --> https://youtu.be/kPuiVrlEZz8

To set up the electronics you can watch this video https://youtu.be/Yh4vhlSzPGI from which I took the idea of making this thing. It's in Spanish, but I'm sure there's a pile of videos in youtube and tutorials over there explaining the same thing in other languages.

I hope you enjoy this and, if you have any question, don't hesitate to post a comment. :D

title: X-UAV Mini Talon Twin Motor Conversion

description.text:
!UPDATE! - 12 March, 2017

I have updated the files with the following changes:
Removed the 1.5 degree downthrust as in testing it was not needed
Smoothed and optimized the shell
Moved the key back far enough to be behind the spar clamp for added security

For more info, here is my build page on this project:
http://www.itsqv.com/QVM/index.php?title=X-UAV_Mini_Talon_Build_Number_3

My test plane flies beautifully the only issue being on launch it is a little more sensitive to how you throw it. I have found the best throws are straight and level with no up or down pitch and at 100% throttle.

This project was done by request and it has come out pretty well so far. Originally I looked at a smaller diameter version as seen on this Thingiverse Bix3 piece -
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:469613

The problem with these Bix2 modules is there is no way to remove the motor without un-glueing the motor pods. The larger diameter fixes this and also creates enough space inside the pod to tuck extra motor wire in for easy connect/disconnect. I did consider adding enough space for a small ESC but this could present issues with too long battery wires as well as heat build-up so I have parked the idea for now.

Key points:

  1. This motor pod/nacelle is designed for a 22XX stator size motor such as a Cobra 2213 or Turnigy SK3 2830. The cross mount holes are 3.1mm and on a 33.5mm bolt circle.

  2. The weight prediction at 25% infill is 27g for PLA but when printed at 35% in ABS, it came out to ~23g.

  3. There is now zero downthrust.

  4. The nacelle is designed to fit just outside the M3 wing clamp hole which gives clearance for up to an 8" prop. Because there is a slight wing taper at this location there is a Left and Right nacelle.

  5. There is a "key" that slots into the rear of the nacelle as added security/strength against bad glue or vibration failure of the joint.

Enjoy and please send a picture or two if you happen to build this!

More Mini Talon Parts!
http://www.itsqv.com/QVM/index.php?title=Mini_Talon_Parts_Compilation

comments.author: koestel

comments.text: Sorry to hear! Could be an angle problem but it doesn't seem likely unless you are way over-powered. The print has only 1-1/2 degrees of down thrust dialed in so that the thrust line is parallel to the fuselage centerline (same as original motor).  You could try adding some washers (~1mm) under the bottom cross mount ears to angle the motors up a little. This will make them very close to the center line of the wing profile. Also, make sure the CoG is on the spar center, 55mm behind the leading edge. I'm building mine now and will see how it goes.

title: Perforated Hollow Wine Bottle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I've been feeling a little artsy lately. After printing a wine bottle as a red herring gift box for a wrapped Christmas present, I started thinking about deceptive containers for other gifts and then how to minimize material use at the same time. This is the first iteration. Hopefully more will come if I continue to get inspired.

Splitting and optionally adding adding a hinge and/or latch, you could use this as a trick gift box like I did, or as-is for a decorative piece.

The perforated bottle design was made by intersecting abstract extrusions through one side of a hollow bottle, then repeating that group radially about the bottle's original central axis to generate the final model.

The full bottle was too tall even for my Extended Ultimaker 2. My split .stl files are available if you're in the same boat.

Some of the overhangs are a bit on the extreme side. I printed without support, and am ok with some of the drooping. If you want a crisper print, consider switching on supports in your slicer.

Ultimaker

description.text:
The original Prusa Iteration 2 X-Idler does not allow the belt to line up with the pulley on the x-motor. I've included pictures showing the issue. This thing moves the wall that holds the 608 bearing toward the rods about 5mm. I changed the following code in the x-idler.scad file:
translate(v = [18.5, -21.5, 25.3]) cube(size = [20.5,7,4.4], center = true); translate(v = [20, 12.5-support_beam_offset, 25.3]) cube(size = [20,5,4.4], center = true); translate(v = [27.5, -5, 7.5+7]) cube(size = [5,40,26], center = true); Also, I used sketchup to round an ugly corner.

title: Bread Tie Prototype
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a proof of concept test for a sort of spring loaded bread wrapper tie.

Assembly Instructions 1) Print the attached model with support, yielding a large cylinder with 2 small pins, and a smaller cylinder. 2) Remove all of the support material. when complete the small cylinder should easily slide though the large cylinder. 3) Bend one leg straight of a 35 mm paper clip. With small pliers bend the tip of that leg 90 degrees for a length of about 2 milimeters. It will act as a hook to pull the rubber band through the 3 mm holes. 4) Put the small cylinder in the large cylinder and align the 3 mm holes, so that the small cylinder sticks up above the large cylinder. 5) Put the papper clip leg through the holes so it pops out the other side. 6) Hang the rubber band on the hook. 7) Pull the rubber band half way into the cylinders. 8) With your fingers, hook the rubber band around the pin. 9) pull the hook the rest of the way through the cylinders. 10) Pull the hook up, and hook the end of the rubber band around the other pin. 11) Remove the hook from the rubber band. The print should be functional at that point.
blank

Update: Had quite a few people order these if you would like me to print them for you please let me know (PM Me) and ill give you a price, Many thanks!

Update 2: Several people have said their boot handle had 6 clips this only has 4.. that's correct, these 4 clips provide a heck of a lot more gripping force as the fixing are a lot more substantial than the original ones. so 6 clips are not needed.

Here are the parts i used to fix my 59 plate Nissan Qashqai boot handle after i heavy handedly snapped it off.. after reading a few automotive forums this is a common fault and at over £100 for a new one i say stick it to the man and repair it yourself

For a good long lasting repair these parts should be printed in nothing else other than ABS this is because the boot handle itself is also ABS meaning you can solvent weld the printed parts to the boot handles with Acetone

comments.author: oderbang

comments.text:
Yeah sure
1) make sure you order it in ABS..
2) Use 100% acetone to join the parts onto the handle it basically welds the parts joining them rather than just gluing them...
3) for an extremely solid result I completely removed all the clips (including ones that were not broken) and sand them flat. Sanding removed the paint and exposes the ABS of the handle and increases surface area for the acetone to work on.
4) I believe there are 6 clips on the original? I just replaced 4 as seen in the picture but my 24 month old can hang of the handle now, its that solid. (i have not modeled the other clips sorry)
5) If you can use a weight on top of the part whilst the solvent evaporates (i left it over night) that also helps.

description.text:
Propeller guards for the 3DR Solo, print with 100% infill.

Print upside down with support (>70 deg angles) and make sure the support is properly removed afterwards. The top/bottom dimensions have only 0.4mm gap with respect to the Solo and if the fit is too tight some break will occur in the layers while mounting.

The clamp fits only one-way with the lid to the left when seen from the motor top.
It can be hard to remove the clamp but pushing a small flat head screwdriver in between the gap should spring it right off.

I added a v2.5 (200 x 200) version which should print fine on a 200 x 200 bed size.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Highly recommended to print in PETG (I used PETG from www.real-filament.com). Risk of layer break when printed in PLA is high!

If you get good results with other filaments please post in the comments.

If you find that your hands cramp up when playing your 3DS, then this grip is what you need! The support in the grip is mostly in the back, as I find that having something to hold with your fingers behind the 3DS really improves the comfort level. As the grip blocks the stylus holder, I also included a clip for the stylus. This also makes it easier to access the stylus for games that go back and forth between touch screen controls and analog controls. If anyone's interested in working off of this, there are some improvements that can be made:
  • The fit is very snug. I leave the grip on, but it may be annoying for someone who wants to take it on and off frequently.
  • The extensions on the top will sometimes hold down the L/R buttons.
  • The headphone jack is blocked. I rarely ever play with headphones on, but this might be a problem for other people.
    • Many thanks to GaryJohnson, who's design I used as a starting point.

• Download files
  • Print the Grip and Notches. Also print the stylus clip, if desired. I printed on a Makerbot Replicator 1 with 3 shells and 20% infill.
  • Fit the notches onto the top pieces of the grip (the image of the model in Rhino shows where they should fit if it's unclear).
  • Fit in the stylus clip
  • Remember to take out the stylus so you can put it in the clip.
  • Snap in your 3DS and enjoy! :)

Replacement clip for broken valence clips on a Venetian blind. I didn't have the piece that broke off, so I had to estimate the final shape based on memory and similar pictures I found using Google.

Prototype was printed in yellow filament, but final versions used clear PLA.

Printer:

Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

I used a flat-bed scanner to capture what was left of the original clip (because it was clear, I coloured in one edge with a black Sharpie marker to make it more distinct). The image was then imported into Inkscape, and the Trace Bitmap Path function was used to capture the outline. Once that was done, the path was edited (in Inkscape) to clean it up and to extend the clip to restore what I assumed was full original shape.

This final path was exported as an SVG, and imported into 123D Design as a sketch, which was then extruded to its final shape.

author: dmarshalko

title: Roman Amphitheatre (reconstruction) - römischen Aphitheater aus Xanten (Rekonstruktion)

description.text:
Roman amphitheatre from the roman city CUT (Xanten, Germany). The original reconstruction can be seen in the Archeological Park Xanten. The modell was created for Z-scale (1:220).
Römisches Amphitheater des römischen Xanten.Die Originalrekonstruktion steht im archäologischen Park. Das Modell wurde angelegt für den Maßstab 1:220 (Spur Z). Durch Spiegeln lässt sich das komplette Oval der Arena herstellen. Zum besseren Ausdruck liegt das Modell zusätzlich in zwei geteilten Dateien vor..
